citing_paper_authors: Yejin, Choi | Claire, Cardie
raw_text: Strictly speaking, negator is not a value for polarity, but we include them in our lexicon, because valence shifters or negators have been shown to play an important role for sentiment analysis (e.g., Polanyi and Zaenen (2004), Moilanen and Pulman (2007), Choi and Cardie (2008))

citing_paper_authors: Yejin, Choi | Claire, Cardie
raw_text: Content-word negators are words that are not function words, but act semantically as negators (Choi and Cardie, 2008) .3 Although it is possible to artificially construct a very convoluted sentence with lots of negations ,itis unlikely for multiple layers of negations to appear very often in natural language (Pickett et al (1996))
clean_text: Content-word negators are words that are not function words, but act semantically as negators (Choi and Cardie, 2008).

raw_text: It makes our task much harder (e.g., Wilson et al (2009)) than those that assume inputs are guaranteed to be either strongly positive or negative (e.g., Pang et al (2002), Choiand Cardie (2008))

citing_paper_authors: Yejin, Choi | Claire, Cardie
raw_text: Performance is reported using 10-fold cross-validation on 400 documents, and a separate 135 documents were used as a development set. For the general-purpose polarity lexicon, we expand the polarity lexicon of Wilson et al (2005) with General Inquirer dictionary as suggested by Choi and Cardie (2008) .We report the performance in two measures: ac curacy for 3-way classification, and average error distance
clean_text: For the general-purpose polarity lexicon, we expand the polarity lexicon of Wilson et al (2005) with General Inquirer dictionary as suggested by Choi and Cardie (2008).

raw_text: According to Choi and Cardie (2008), voting algorithms that recognize content-word negators achieve a competitive performance, so we will use a variant of it for simplicity
clean_text: According to Choi and Cardie (2008), voting algorithms that recognize content-word negators achieve a competitive performance, so we will use a variant of it for simplicity.
